todos.title: Words
todos.body: Use customer, price, invoice, and team, not client, fee, bill, and staff.

todos.title: Price Sensitivity
todos.body: Substitute effect, value effect, switching cost, comparison effect, quality effect, expenditure effect, end-benefit effect, shared cost, effect, fairness,  inventory.

todos.title: Anti-Intellectual Capital
todos.body: Rigid adherence to old methods.

todos.title: Buyer Identification Pricing
todos.body: Pricing by seniors, children, students, nonprofits, coupons.

todos.title: Purchase Location Pricing
todos.body: Pricing by location, having different offices, etc.

todos.title: Price Customer
todos.body: Price the customer, not the product or service.

todos.title: Structural Capital/Infrastructure
todos.body: Organizational structure, policies, intellectual property rights, documented systems, management contracts, employee development and education, proprietary systems, customer lists, contracts.

todos.title: Product Design Pricing
todos.body: Offering different versions of a product of service.

todos.title: Pride
todos.body: Is a more effective motivator of talent than money.

todos.title: Innovation revenue
todos.body: Income from products that didn't exist X years ago.

todos.title: Three Types of Intellectual Capital
todos.body: Human, structural, and social.  Structural capital is the only one that is owned by the firm.  This is why infrastructure is so important.  Human and social knowledge must be gained from people.

todos.title: Eight Steps for Value Pricing
todos.body: Have a conversation with the customer, price the customer, develop pricing options, present options to customer, customer selection, project management, change orders, project evaluations.

todos.title: Evaluation
todos.body: Evaluation of the experience is more important than the experience.  What was supposed to happen, what happened (ground truth), what were the positive and negative factors, what have we learned, how can we do better, who needs to know these lessons, who will implement these lessons.

todos.title: Chief Value Officer Advice
todos.body: Don't be a wimpy pricer, a lot of times you have to say no, people are scared of change, customer owns the shop, no one is in control, decisions are our most important resource, focus on others and you will become important, one wrong doesn't overcome another, lay a foundation.  (Brendon Harrex)

todos.title: Profits
todos.body: Derive from risk.

todos.title: Institution
todos.body: Compressed Expertise

todos.title: Mutual Gain v. Equal Gain
todos.body: both parties must profit but it does not have to be in equal proportion.

todos.title: Inflection Point
todos.body: A time in the life of a business in which its fundamentals are about to change.

todos.title: Valued Employee
todos.body: A person's worth to an organization can be measured by the amount of supervision they require.

todos.title: Testing New Ideas
todos.body: You should know how much of your firms human capital is dedicated to testing new ideas vs. executing old ones.

todos.title: Change Order
todos.body: You should define the customer requirements in your scope and if the customer does not meet them there is a change order.

todos.title: You are Your Customer
todos.body: You are as good or bad as your customer list.

todos.title: Knowledge Worker
todos.body: Worker who directs their attention to the most valuable things to do.

todos.title: Convenience Buyers
todos.body: Willing to pay higher price for exactly what they want exactly when they want it.

todos.title: Pre-Action
todos.body: What our the intended results, what challenges can we anticipate, what have we or others learned from similar situations, what will make us successful this time.

todos.title: Avoid Competition
todos.body: War destroys, commerce builds.

todos.title: Peer Review
todos.body: Using anonymous cards to grade customers, employees, etc.

todos.title: Two Part / Tie In Pricing
todos.body: Two separate charges for one product or experience (ex razor and blade, door charge and drink charge).

todos.title: Purpose of Business
todos.body: To create a customer and to create wealth for that customer.

todos.title: No Commodity
todos.body: There is no such thing as a commodity, everything can be differentiated.

todos.title: Threshold
todos.body: There is an upper and lower price threshold in every customer.  Map the ranges and figure out how to discriminate so you can fall in everyone's range.

todos.title: Gossen's Law
todos.body: The market price is determined by what the last unit of a product is worth to people.

todos.title: Shut Up
todos.body: The best salesmen know exactly the right time to shut up when making a pitch.  Don't talk yourself out of a sale.

todos.title: Expectations
todos.body: The best firms are constantly questioning their customers expectations.  You need to know the expectations with every involvement.  When a customer pays you to solve one problem, you need to solve two for them.

todos.title: Tacit v. Explicit Knowledge
todos.body: Tacit knowledge is like describing how to ride a bike.  It is rich with detail and experience.  Explicit knowledge is can be easily described or stored on a medium.  Tacit knowledge can become explicit via database, paper, report, manual, video, picture, etc.

todos.title: Price Sensitivity Factors
todos.body: Substitutes, value, switching costs, comparison, price-quality, pass through expense, fairness.

todos.title: Value Buyers
todos.body: Study alternatives and features well before choosing best value.  Don't always by the cheapest.  Can be persuaded with loyalty programs.

todos.title: Customer Segments
todos.body: Splitting customers into first class (5 to 8% in planes), business class (15 to 24%), full fare (30 to 50%), coach (15 to 35%) and discount (10 to 20%).  Don't misallocate resources to lower value customers.

todos.title: Penetration Pricing
todos.body: Setting price below the value to establish a larger customer base.

todos.title: Neutral Pricing
todos.body: Setting price at value.

todos.title: Skim Pricing
todos.body: Setting price above value to establish a higher perceived value.

todos.title: Scope Document Elements
todos.body: Scope statement, objectives, constraints, structure, roles, team, assumptions, deliverables, change control, future projects list, approval.

todos.title: Wealth
todos.body: Resides in the intellectual capital of a company.

todos.title: Diamond Effect
todos.body: Rare, desired, and impossible to duplicate.  Doesn't have to have utility to be valuable and profitable.

todos.title: Purchase Quantity Pricing
todos.body: Quantity discounts.

todos.title: Atarimae Hinshitsu
todos.body: Quality is taken for granted.  Number one complaint is not quality but rather lousy service.

todos.title: Time of Purchase Pricing
todos.body: Pricing by time of purchase, time of product, or turnaround time for delivery.

todos.title: Relationship Buyers
todos.body: Place high value on brand, quality, and relationships.

todos.title: Economic Buyer
todos.body: Person who makes the decisions.

todos.title: Cost of Others
todos.body: People will have different pricing thresholds depending on whether they are paying or using someone else's money and whether the purchase is for them or someone else.

todos.title: Purchasing
todos.body: People buy emotionally and justify intellectually.

todos.title: Price Options
todos.body: Offer an array of options to maximize customer value.

todos.title: Knowledge Management Software/Knowledge Bank
todos.body: Not a system but a culture of knowledge inputs (adding knowledge) and outputs (accessing knowledge).

todos.title: Napster v. ITunes
todos.body: Napster revolutionized the music business, iTunes profited from the revolution of the music business.

todos.title: Starting Point
todos.body: Mr. Customer, we will only undertake or charge for the engagement if we can provide value that is three times our price.  Is that acceptable?

todos.title: Price Buyers
todos.body: Looking for the lowest price, should be offered the stripped down version of your service.

todos.title: Price
todos.body: Language in which a company strategically communicates value to a customer.

todos.title: Value
todos.body: Is in the eye of the beholder.

todos.title: TIP Clause
todos.body: In the event that we are able to satisfy you needs in a timely and professional maker, you have agreed to review the situation and decide whether, in the sole discretion of XYZ, some additional payment to ABC is appropriate in view of your overall satisfaction with services rendered by ABC.

todos.title: Confidence
todos.body: If you do not think you are worth your pricing, your customers never will.

todos.title: Tragedy of Commons
todos.body: If everyone owns something than no one does and no one will care for it.

todos.title: Business Model
todos.body: How your firm creates value for customers and how you monetize that value.

todos.title: Equality
todos.body: He who seeks equality should go find a cemetery.

todos.title: Hard v Soft Data
todos.body: Hard data is numbers and facts, soft data is gossip, hearsay, and intuition.  Sometimes what counts can't be counted and what can be counted doesn't count.

todos.title: Customer Grading
todos.body: Grading customers with A, B, C'

todos.title: Numbers
todos.body: Give the illusion of presenting more truth and precision than they are capable of doing.  Numbers, studies, and reports should be used to start a discussion and guide strategy.  They should not be followed blindly.

todos.title: Stop Old Things
todos.body: For a firm to be innovative it must stop doing old things.

todos.title: Customer Pricing
todos.body: Firm says this is what it will cost us, what would you like to pay.  If the customer is unfair then they decline to do further work.

todos.title: Little Touch Management
todos.body: Finding special but not expensive ways to take care of clients.

todos.title: Customer Benefit
todos.body: Don't tell me how good you make it, tell me how good it makes me when I use it. (Leo Burnett).  Customers by good feelings and solutions to their problems.

todos.title: Firing Customers
todos.body: Don't let bad customers get in the way of good customers.  Also known as forced churn.

todos.title: Pricing Guarantees
todos.body: Don't forget to include the cost of any guarantees or warrantees you attach to your product/service.

todos.title: Creep
todos.body: Do not let team members change scope without correct approvals.

todos.title: High Satisfaction Day
todos.body: Day that convinces you why you do what you do.

todos.title: Listening
todos.body: Customer should talk twice as much as the salesperson.  Talkers dominate the conversation but listeners control it.

todos.title: Good Pricing
todos.body: Clients screened, understanding customer values, price leverage, knowledge of cost to serve, mutual gain, slow process of pricing, ignore competitors, differentiation, negotiation.

todos.title: Cardinal v Ordinal Ranking
todos.body: Cardinal ranking has a value that can be added, subtracted, etc.  An ordinal vale is a position on a list (ex fifth).

todos.title: Product Bundling
todos.body: Bundling two products to raise sale but discounting individual products.

todos.title: Ideas v Execution
todos.body: Apple charges $400 for a phone, $50 goes towards making the phone and $350 towards research, design, and profit.

todos.title: Efficaciousness
todos.body: Ability to produce a desired effect.

todos.title: Professional
todos.body: A technician who cares.

todos.title: Advertising
todos.body: A tax for having an unremarkable product.

todos.title: Crowbar
todos.body: A man buying a crowbar to open a treasure chest will pay well above market value for the crowbar.

todos.title: Transformation Business
todos.body: A company that helps customers achieve more and greater.
